required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Change Club Study: Evaluation of Civic Engagement for Built Environment Change and Health Improvement
clinical_study.official_title: The Change Club Study: Evaluation of Civic Engagement for Built Environment Change and Health Improvement

brief_summary.textblock: This is a community randomized controlled trial to evaluate a civic engagement curriculum through which residents will identify barriers and facilitators to healthy eating and physical activity and then implement a project in their communities.

detailed_description.textblock:
The purpose of this research is to better understand how resident-led activities to change the community environment affect health. The Change Club is a small group of residents who will try to change their community environment relative to food (for example, foods in restaurants or schools) or physical activity opportunities (for example, parks or walking trails) by following a step-wise process facilitated by an extension educator. The purpose of this research is to better understand if and how these activities affect individual behaviors (for example physical activity) and health outcomes (for example blood pressure) of adults in rural communities.
This study will take place in 12 designated rural communities in Texas and New York. It is planned that about 2,260 people will participate in this study. Some will participate as Change Club members; some will participate as family and friends of Change Club members; and others will participate as community residents.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in American Heart Association's Life's Simple 7 (LS7) cardiovascular health score
primary_outcome.description: American Heart Association's Life's Simple 7 (LS7) score is a composite of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors (physical activity, eating habits, smoking status, cholesterol, glucose, body mass index (BMI), and blood pressure). Score ranges from 0 to 14. Higher scores indicate better health.

secondary_outcome.description: Height and weight will be measured and BMI will be calculated.
Systolic blood pressure (mmHg) will be measured.
Diastolic blood pressure (mmHg) will be measured.
Resting heart rate (BPM) will be measured.
Total cholesterol (mg/dL) will be measured.
HDL cholesterol (mg/dL) will be measured.
LDL cholesterol (mg/dL) will be measured.
Triglycerides (mg/dL) will be measured.
Fasting blood glucose levels (mg/dL) will be measured.
General health status will be assessed using the 36-Item Short Form Survey (SF-36) general health scale. Scores range from 0 to 100. Higher scores indicate better health.
Whether or not a participant currently smokes will be assessed using an LS7 item.

Total Healthy Eating Index (HEI) score will be calculated from a single 24-hour recall collected via the Automated Self-Administered 24-hour Dietary Assessment Tool (ASA24). Score ranges from 0 to 100. Higher scores indicate better diet.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in fruit and vegetable intake
secondary_outcome.description: Total fruit and vegetable intake (cups/day) will be measured by the National Cancer Institute Fruit and Vegetable Screener (NCI FVS).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in consumption of whole grains
secondary_outcome.description: Whole grain consumption (servings/day) will be assessed using an LS7 item.
Whether or not a participant met the recommendation for fish consumption will be assessed using an LS7 item.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in total dietary quality score
secondary_outcome.description: Total dietary score will be assessed by adapting the Colby et al. Short Healthy Eating Index (sHEI) survey. Score ranges from 0 to 100. Higher scores indicate better diet.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in total steps per day
secondary_outcome.description: Total steps per day will be calculated using the average of self-reported pedometer readings.
Total physical activity (MET min/wk) will be assessed using the International Physical Activity Questionnaire long form (IPAQ-long).
Total sitting time (hrs/wk) will be assessed using the International Sedentary Assessment Tool (ISAT).
Healthy eating motivation will be assessed by the Naughton & McCarthy Healthy Eating Motivation scale. Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater motivation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in confidence for healthy eating
secondary_outcome.description: Confidence for healthy eating will be assessed by the Sallis Eating Habits Confidence Survey (20-item). Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater confidence.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in confidence for healthy eating (expanded)
secondary_outcome.description: Confidence for healthy eating will also be assessed using a newly created Expanded Eating Habits Confidence scale (25-item). Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater confidence.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in social support for healthy eating scale
secondary_outcome.description: Social support (family and friends) for healthy eating will be assessed by the Ball Social Support for Healthy Eating scale. Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater social support.

Exercise attitudes will be assessed using selected items from section 2, question 5 of the AARP Exercise Attitudes and Behaviors Survey. Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate more positive attitudes.
Exercise confidence will be assessed by the Sallis Exercise Confidence Survey. Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater confidence.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in social support for physical activity
secondary_outcome.description: Social support (family and friends) for physical activity will be assessed by the Ball Social Support for Physical Activity scale. Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater social support.
Social engagement (family and friends) will be assessed by the Lubben Social Network Scale. Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater social engagement.

Change in social (group) identity scores will be assessed by group affiliation ratings from the Haslam et al. Exeter Identity Transitions Scale (EXITS). Scores range from 1 to 7. Higher scores indicate stronger group identity.

Community social cohesion will be assessed by the social cohesion sub-scale of the Mujahid et al. Neighborhood Environment Scale (NES). Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater social cohesion.

Social issues advocacy will be assessed by an adaptation of the Nilsson et al. Social Issues Advocacy Scale. Scores range from 1 to 5. High scores indicate more positive attitudes and behaviors indicative of social justice advocacy.
Individual mobilization will be assessed by selected items from the Jakes & Shannon Mobilization Scale - Individual. Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater mobilization.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in general civic engagement attitudes
secondary_outcome.description: Civic engagement attitudes will be assessed by the attitudes sub-scale of the Doolittle & Faul Civic Engagement Scale. Scores range from 1 to 7. Higher scores indicate more positive civic engagement attitudes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in general civic engagement behaviors
secondary_outcome.description: Civic engagement behaviors will be assessed by the behaviors sub-scale of the Doolittle & Faul Civic Engagement Scale. Scores range from 1 to 7. Higher scores indicate more frequent civic engagement behaviors.

Mindset and expectations will be assessed using a scale from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation (RWJF) National Survey of Health Attitudes. Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater understanding of community determinants of health.
Community membership will be assessed using the Sense of Community Index 2 (SCI-2). Scores range from 1 to 4. Higher scores indicate greater membership within the community.
Community connection will be assessed using the SCI-2. Scores range from 1 to 4. Higher scores indicate greater emotional connection with community members.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in investment in community health
secondary_outcome.description: Investment in community health (number of priorities) will be assessed using questions from the RWJF National Survey of Health Attitudes. Scores range from 0 to 5. Higher scores indicate higher priority placed on community health.
Walking environment will be assessed by the walking sub-scale of the NES. Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate more favorable walking environments.
Neighborhood safety will be assessed by the neighborhood safety sub-scale of the NES. Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater neighborhood safety.
Neighborhood aesthetic quality will be assessed by the aesthetic sub-scale of the NES. Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate more favorable aesthetics.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in fresh fruit and vegetable availability
secondary_outcome.description: Fresh fruit and vegetable availability will be assessed by the fresh fruit and vegetables sub-scale of the Green & Glanz Perceived Nutrition Environment Measures Survey (NEMS-P). Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater availability.
Store access will be assessed by the store access sub-scale from NEMS-P. Scores range from 4 to 14. Higher scores indicate greater store access.
Store selection motivation will be assessed by the store selection motivation sub-scale from NEMS-P. Scores range from 1 to 4. Higher scores indicate greater motivation.
Restaurant access will be assessed by the restaurant access sub-scale from NEMS-P. Scores range from 3 to 11. Higher scores indicate greater access to restaurants.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in restaurant healthy food availability
secondary_outcome.description: Restaurant healthy food availability will be assessed by the restaurant healthy food availability sub-scale from NEMS-P. Scores range from 1 to 5. Higher scores indicate greater availability of healthy food in restaurants.

arm_group.description: For Change Club members (CCM) only: CCM will participate in meetings of the Change Club weekly for six months and continue implementation of a change to the community environment for up to an additional 24 months. Change Club members will also be asked to recruit 10 or more friends and family members (FFM) to participate in the research study. In addition, 100 community residents (CR) will be recruited into the study. Family members, friends and community residents do not participate in the Change Club, but may hear about Change Club activities in their community.
Control group participants will participate in no intervention activities during the 4-year research study.

intervention.description: The investigators will evaluate the efficacy of the CC curriculum in a 24-months community-based randomized controlled trial. They will compare changes in CVD-related anthropometric, physiologic, behavioral, and psychosocial parameters between subjects in 6 intervention and 6 control communities.
Group 2 will be offered the same activities as Group 1 after the conclusion of the research study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
We will be recruiting Change Club members (CCM), friend and family members (FFM) of CCM, and community residents (CR). Some CR's will participate in full data collection (CR Full Data) while others will only participate in the online survey (CR Survey Only).
Common inclusion criteria include:
- Age 18-99
- English-speaking
CCM also must:
- Provide consent electronically
- Be willing to be randomized to either group
- Be willing to recruit 10 or more family members and/or friends
- Score "poor" on at least one of the Simple 7 composite score items (e.g. not meeting Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans)
- Live in one of 12 designated towns in NY and TX
FFM also must:
- Provide consent electronically
- Be family members or friends identified by a CCM
CR also must:
- Provide consent electronically
- Live in one of 12 designated towns in NY and TX
Exclusion Criteria:
- Cognitive impairment (if it precludes completion of assessments and/or intervention)
- Inability to communicate due to severe, uncorrectable hearing loss or speech disorder (if it precludes completion of assessments and/or intervention)
- Severe visual impairment (if it precludes completion of assessments and/or intervention)
- Inability to read (as it precludes completion of assessments and/or intervention)
- Already included in another study sample (e.g. CR cannot also be CCM)
